speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Danis (for the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)) moved
speakerposition: Minister of Labour
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
that Bill S-2, an act to implement conventions between Canada and Finland, Canada and the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic and Canada and the United Mexican States for the avoidance of double taxation with respect to income tax and the prevention of fiscal evasion and a convention between Canada and the United Mexican States for the exchange of information with respect to taxes be read the second time and referred to Legislative committee F.
He said: Madam Speaker, I am pleased on behalf of the government to begin the debate on Bill S-2, an act to implement tax conventions between Canada and Finland, Canada and Czechoslovakia, Canada and Mexico, and an exchange of information treaty with Mexico.
The purpose of this bill is to implement conventions between Canada and Finland, Canada and the Czechoslovak Federal Republic, and Canada and the United Mexican States for the avoidance of double taxation with respect to income tax and a convention between Canada and the United Mexican States for the exchange of information with respect to taxes.
The role of tax treaties is to promote international trade and facilitate international investment. The existence of tax treaties generates an air of stability for investors by providing certainty both as to the method
and the rates of taxation of income flowing between two countries.
Tax treaties also seek to eliminate or alleviate double taxation of income arising from international transactions. The three tax treaties under review follow the pattern of treaties previously approved by Parliament. The major reform of Canada's income tax legislation in 1971 required Canada both to expand its network of tax treaties and to revise treaties previously concluded with other countries.
Negotiations have resulted in the conclusion of new or revised treaties with almost 75 countries. Canada now has 50 tax treaties in force. The bill before the House today represents a continuation of that process.
The rates of tax provided in a treaty cannot be increased unless the treaty itself is revised.
Any revision requires the agreement of the two governments and is a lengthy process. Termination of a treaty is a rare event. As an example, I would note that Canada terminated its treaty with South Africa in 1985. Both in the case of a revision of a treaty and the termination of a treaty, taxpayers are given advance notice of the changes.
Administrative benefits are also provided for taxpayers under our tax treaties. The requirement to pay tax on business profits in the country of source, that is, in the country where the profit is actually made, is eliminated unless the taxpayer has a permanent establishment in that country. A mechanism is provided under the terms of the treaty to settle various problems encountered by taxpayers both as to the interpretation and the application of the treaty.
One of the most important aspects of tax treaties is the elimination or the alleviation of double taxation. Double taxation of international transactions arises when the same income is taxed in the hands of the same person by two different countries. It generally occurs because of the difference in taxation legislation of the two countries.

This type of double taxation arises in three situation: first, where each contracting state-the two states that are involved in the particular treaty-subjects the same person to tax on a world-wide income; second, where a person is a resident of a contracting state and derives income from the other contracting state and both state imposes tax on that income; and third, where each contracting state subjects the same person, not being a resident of either contracting state, to tax on income derived from a contracting state. This may result, for instance, in a situation where a non-resident person has a permanent establishment in one contracting state through which income is derived from the other contracting state.
per cent-15 per cent in the case of Mexico-will apply. There are, however, a number of exceptions.
Interest paid in respect of a bond or similar obligation of the government, a political subdivision or local authority thereof, is exempt in the country in which it arises. Also, the three treaties contain a provision that would allow that interest paid in respect of a loan made, guaranteed or insured, or a credit extended, guaranteed or insured by a certain state entities-in Canada for example the Export Development Corporation-be taxable only in the state where the recipient of such interest resides.
Tax treaties eliminate double taxation in these situations by either providing one of the states with the exclusive right to tax or by ensuring that taxes paid in one state can be used to offset taxes payable in the other state.
Treaties confer on only one of the contracting states an exclusive right to tax a number of items of income. For these items of income, double taxation is avoided since the other contracting state is prevented from taxing.
For some items of income, the right to tax is not an exclusive one. The treaties confer on the state of source a full or limited right to tax. Although the state of residence of the taxpayer may also tax these items of income, the treaty allows relief for the taxes paid to the other state so as to avoid double taxation.
I would now like to briefly indicate the main elements of these tax treaties. I will deal with the exchange of information convention later in my remarks.
These treaties provide generally that dividends may be taxed in the source country at a maximum rate of 15 per cent. However, in the case of dividends paid to a company that is resident of a contracting state, a 10 per cent rate will apply if the company receiving the dividends holds an equity interest of at least 10 per cent-25 per cent in the case of the treaty with Mexico-of the voting power of the company paying the dividends.
In the case of interest paid by a resident of one country to a resident of the other country, a general rate of 10
With respect to royalties, the conventions provide for a general rate of 10 per cent-15 in the case of Mexico-in the source country. Copyright royalties in respect of most cultural or artistic works are generally exempt under the three treaties. In the case of Czechoslovakia and Mexico, they must be subject to tax in the state where the recipient resides in order to qualify for the exemption from taxation at source.
Some of the other matters also dealt with in these treaties include the subject of capital gains. The treaty provision dealing with capital gains reflects the standard Canadian position enabling the source country to tax gains arising on the sale of real property, business assets and shares in real estate companies.
Second, non-discrimination. Under the treaties, discrimination on the basis of nationality is prohibited, thereby ensuring nationals of a country equal treatment with nationals of the other country in the same circumstances. However, this does not prevent a country from providing fiscal incentives-for example, a small business deduction-on the basis of the residence of the taxpayer.
Third, pensions. Canada has preserved its right to tax pensions paid to residents of Czechoslovakia, Finland and Mexico. In the case of Czechoslovakia and Mexico, the maximum rate of tax applicable by a contracting state to periodic pension and annuity payments to residents of the other state is 15 per cent. In the case of Finland, the maximum rate of tax applicable to periodic pension payments is 20 per cent. Finally war veterans pensions are generally exempt from tax under the three treaties.
February 7, 1992

Government Orders
Fourth, double taxation relief. The treaties provide that in Canada double taxation of foreign source income of Canadian residents is alleviated by way of a foreign tax credit, in accordance with the limitations provided for in the Canadian legislation. In addition, dividends received by a company resident in Canada from the exempt surplus of its foreign affiliate resident in a treaty country are exempt from tax in Canada. Reciprocally relief from double taxation is granted in the other treaty country in accordance with a method recognized by that country.
As to the exchange of information convention with Mexico, this exchange of information convention was signed before the signature of the comprehensive double tax convention referred to previously. It is limited to the exchange of tax information between Canada and Mexico and will be used as a complement to exchange of information provisions found in the comprehensive treaty.
The exchange of information convention will assist the revenue authorities in combating tax evasion. It allows three types of exchange of information: (1) information that will be sent to the other state on a regular and automatic basis, (2) information that will be sent to the other state on a spontaneous basis when it comes to the attention of the sending state, and (3) information that is specifically requested by the other state.
The convention contains a number of safeguards intended to ensure that the information will only be provided for tax purposes and only if providing such information would not violate any law, disclose any trade secret or impose on a state the obligation to carry out measures different from its normal administrative practices.
In conclusion, Madam Speaker, equitable solutions are provided under the terms of these three tax conventions for the various problems of double taxation existing between Canada and these countries. The exchange of information convention with Mexico represents a complement to the comprehensive tax treaty with that country. Each of these countries hopes to implement the bilateral convention as soon as possible and consequently I commend this bill to the most favourable consideration of this House.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I wish to take part in this debate on Bill S-2, an act to implement conventions between Canada and Finland, Canada and the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic and Canada and the United Mexican States for the avoidance of double taxation with respect to income tax and the prevention of fiscal evasion and a convention between Canada and the United Mexican States for the exchange of information with respect to taxes.
You can understand that, with such a title, this bill is hard to read and understand. Reading the four conventions attached to this bill is a difficult exercise for a member of this House.

As a lawyer, even I find the words extremely difficult.
However, the purpose of this bill, which is to avoid double taxation and to prevent fiscal evasion, that is evasion of taxes between the countries that are signatories to the various conventions, is a worth-while one. As the parliamentary secretary has stated, there are 50 such conventions in force at the present time. This act will bring into place three more that deal with those two issues and the additional one with Mexico to provide for the exchange of information.
If I may say, Madam Speaker, when I was practising law on a regular basis, I occasionally had some dealings with these conventions and their application in respect of the Income Tax Act of Canada. I note, as the parliamentary secretary I think stated, these conventions take precedence over the Income Tax Act. The bill before us ensures that in one of its provisions. In other words, where there is a conflict between the Income Thx Act and the convention, the convention takes precedence.
Obviously our main convention is with the United States. It is the one most frequently dealt with in this country by tax experts. I may say that I was not a tax expert. In reading the U.S. convention and trying to decide how it took precedence over the Income Ikx Act and over which section is always a bit of a conundrum. Usually I end up relying on advice from the Department of National Revenue. I can only hope that advice was always correct. After all, they are the ones who interpret

Government Orders
the act for their own purposes. They are the ones also involved in it on a regular basis and presumably know how it would be applied.
One of my partners, Mr. David Bonham, who is an expert, can cite the Canada-U.S. tax treaty chapter and verse, but I never had such facility with the technical language of the treaty, let alone the technical language of the Income Ikx Act, which is even worse, as most people who have had any dealings with it can attest.
However, in dealing with this bill, I suggest the proper course is to have the bill referred to a legislative committee where it can receive the detailed study that it deserves to ensure that the words of the act are sufficient to bring the treaties into full force and also to review the treaties to see that they are in accordance with past practices in this regard.
I note that in the material provided to us to assist in dealing with this bill, it is stated that the treaties are generally patterned on the model Double Taxation Convention prepared by the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development. The committee will want to ensure that is the case in the course of its deliberations.
I notice also that the treaties were signed by the Minister of National Revenue, the Minister of Finance and now the minister of fisheries. I assume they were signed at different times when those ministers occupied various other portfolios. I can imagine that the ministers spent a great deal of time negotiating these important treaties and making sure the words were entirely satisfactory for Canada. Perhaps if they had spent a little more time here, we would not be in the fiscal mess that we are in this country today. Anyway, I am sure the parliamentary secretary will speak to them in that regard and encourage them to devote their efforts to fixing up the fiscal mess in Canada rather than dealing necessarily with these treaties, helpful as they may be.
However, Canadian taxpayers ultimately should be the beneficiary under these arrangements, especially those taxpayers who have assets in foreign countries and are subject to taxation there because it will provide for the avoidance of double taxation on their incomes derived from those places and will also assist the Canadian government, on the other hand, in ensuring that taxes
are paid by those who are earning foreign income and may wish to avoid payment on it for various reasons.
Perhaps we are all the net beneficiaries as a result of these treaties. The committee will want to look into it. We are pleased to (a) support the bill and (b) assist in ensuring its swift passage in order that the detailed consideration it deserves can be forthcoming. I am sure the bill will be reported back to the House and dealt with at third reading in due course.

Madam Speaker, it is quite common for these bills with respect to tax treaties between Canada and other countries to come up in the House, to be treated rather briefly, have them go to committee, have them come back and be passed. I think that is appropriate because they generally are not matters of contention between the parties. There is a standard procedure that exists between some countries and that we hope will come to exist between Canada and all countries, that these kinds of understandings be reached and be enshrined in legislation. This is a special one. I am not saying that we are going to obstruct it in any significant way. We too want to see it go to committee quickly, have it looked at and sent back. We do not intend to vote against the bill, but we do intend to use this opportunity just for a little while to talk about the relationship between Canada and one of the countries to which this bill applies. That is, of course, the relationship between Canada and Mexico.
This bill provides for an exchange of information with respect to taxes between Canada and Mexico. I am sure the government will argue that this exchange of information with respect to taxes is simply a matter of obtaining the information that is necessary in order to draft the appropriate regulations pursuant to the legislation.
We also think that this question of exchange of information between Canada and Mexico could be related or preparatory in some way for the North American Free Trade Agreement which the government would like to sign with the United States and Mexico. At the very least, we would like to argue that there has not been enough exchange of information about Canada-Mexico relations here in this House, never mind between Canada and Mexico.
Just this very week the hon. member for Esquimalt- Juan de Fuca wanted the Minister of State for Small Businesses, or for that matter the Minister for International Trade, to table in this House documents which are
February 7, 1992

reported to be available to Mexican politicians with respect to the negotiations going on now between Canada, the United States and Mexico. We were not able to obtain that document. We have had further proof since that these so-called draft agreements actually exist and that Mexican senators have had access to these draft agreements. Yet, we here in the Canadian House of Commons, on the other side of the negotiations, are still left in the dark. We cannot see these agreements. To spend money in Burma for oil development and spend money in Siberia for oil development.
I am talking about these tax treaties and our Income Thx Act which say that these companies get every cent spent in those foreign nations back on their taxable income as a deduction here in this country, every single penny spent. Imagine if every Canadian had that kind of a deal. Imagine, every penny spent by a Canadian company in Burma for an oil development will be returned to the company as a deduction from its taxable income.
The system operates like this. In the income tax return of an oil company, for example, as we see in this treaty today there is a deduction called-and let us be fair about this, there are deductions for Canadian development of oil, gas and mines, there are deductions for Canadian exploration-"foreign exploration and development".
This is the way it works. A company can take from its taxable income in Canada 10 per cent of what it invested in a foreign nation or the profits it made in a foreign nation from oil and gas development, either one, until 100 per cent is recovered. Of course the same thing applies to Canada, does it not? Gulf, in pulling out of Hibernia and being committed to 243 more days of payments into the project though it is no longer there, can get back the $370 million it spent because 100 per cent of its investment can be taken from its taxable income regardless of whether it is in Canada or a foreign nation.
I looked at this bill today. The hon. parliamentary secretary stood in the House and said: "They are all the same". Well, they are not all the same. All of the 50 other tax arrangements he mentioned are not all the same. This agreement with Finland he just asked me about a few moments ago has a section which says this: "Earnings means the profits after deducting therefrom $500,000 Canadian". Madam Speaker, do you know what that is? That is the deduction on capital gains. It was introduced a few years ago. It is in this bill as it applies to
Government Orders
profits and gains. The policy of the Government of Canada is that it is only $100,000 now but if they invest in Finland it is $500,000.
That is not in the agreement with Czechoslovakia or Mexico. The hon. parliamentary secretary said: "Oh, just look at it. Just pass it all. It is all the same". It is not all the same at all. However, I will tell you what is the same.
The rationale for allowing an oil and gas company under our income tax laws, not any other company investing in foreign nations, to be able to deduct the money it spends in a foreign nation is-and the tax department and the tax experts in Revenue Canada will tell you this, they told it to me a hundred times because I have argued with them- if you do not allow a company to deduct all of its expenses overseas it will pull up its roots in Canada and will set up an establishment in that foreign country. That foreign country will then tax its profits, not the Canadian government.
All one needs to do is look at any of these conventions. What do you see? You see a description of where the company pays its taxes. Does it pay it here if it invests in Siberia as Gulf Canada is doing? Does it pay its taxes on its profits here in Canada if it is investing in Burma as Petro-Canada is doing after it closed down a thousand service stations the other day?
The law and the income tax department are pretty difficult things to get around. It spells it out pretty clearly, and I want to put it on the record because it destroys the argument used by Revenue Canada. It destroys the argument used by the Government of Canada that you need to give a 100 per cent write-off for investing in a foreign nation.
Companies are taxed on the basis of which state is the contracting one. In other words, a Canadian company investing in Siberia would be considered to be the contracting state. It says: "By reason of domicile or residence or place of management". Then it says: "Supposing there is a residence in both countries", and then: "A permanent home will be the criteria".
What if there is a permanent home in both countries? Then it will be determined by your personal and economic relations, wherever that takes place; in other words, under law, the centre of vital interest.
What if the business proves it has personal and economic relations in both of those countries? Then it boils down to where it is a national. If it is a national in

February 7, 1992
both countries then it is up to negotiations between the states.
In other words, this argument that somebody, a company or a business, can just set up an office in Siberia or set one up in Burma because it is pulling out of Hibernia, off the coast of Newfoundland, and pay taxes in that country is a complete and utter fallacy. It is a complete and utter fallacy.
It is an argument put forward by people who say and who believe that certain people should not pay taxes. If you are big enough, if you are rich enough, if you are influential enough, if you lobby enough, if you can afford the big guys then you should not pay taxes.
That is the system promoted by this bill. Did you notice what the tax on dividends is? You know what it is? It can only go up to 10 per cent.
Madam Speaker, I understand you are getting ready to cut me off.

In the letter the man asked me to help find his son who had disappeared some 18 months ago.
I was in Sri Lanka on a human rights fact finding mission with a group of distinguished Canadians, including my hon. colleagues from Nepean and Burnaby- Kingsway.
Little did I know that that man's letter would be the first of 261 personal submissions I would receive from people whose sons, daughters or spouses have simply disappeared.
The peace committee in Batticaloa has documented 3,418 such disappearances since June 1990.
We concluded that a tragedy of appalling proportion is occurring in Sri Lanka and frankly the government and the insurgent LTTE are equally to blame.
Only third party intervention will stop the killing and hopefully lead to a negotiated settlement. I urge the Government of Canada to show leadership through the United Nations, the Commonwealth or, better still, the-

Madam Speaker, Sri Lanka, incredibly beautiful with enormous potential, is being decimated by an ethnic conflict between the state and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Elam.
There are human rights violations on both sides of the conflict: kidnapping, massacres, individuals held for ransom, forced removal of Muslim population and arbitrary detention.
There is a climate of distrust, fear and repression throughout the country. Media is state controlled. Two hundred and fifty thousand people live in refugee camps. Every young male Thmil is in fear of persecution. Women and children are without proper food and health supplies.
Canada must take a lead position at the United Nations. Canada must ensure there is a complete embargo on all arms exports to Sri Lanka and must call on the international community to do likewise.
Canada should press the Sri Lankan government and the LTTE through the international community to agree to an immediate cease-fire. Canada should suspend the part of Canadian development assistance that is channelled through the Sri Lankan government. These funds should be reallocated to other programs in Sri Lanka.

On Tuesday of this week, February 4, Gulf Oil Canada announced its required eight-month notice that it was withdrawing from the Hibernia offshore megaproject.
The remaining three consortium members, Mobil Oil, Petro-Canada and Chevron, together with the federal government, have vowed that the project will go ahead as scheduled and remain within the budget.

Despite the announcement of business as usual, I have become aware that Gulf's announcement has added a great deal of uncertainty regarding Hibernia's development and has the considerable potential of dampening future business opportunities in Newfoundland and in Canada.

Americans spend $2,600 per person or 12 per cent of their GNP for health care. Canadians spend only $1,900 per person or 9 per cent of their GNP. Yet, despite spending 30 per cent more, 34 million Americans have no health coverage and 50 million more have inadequate health coverage.
So who has the better health care system? Is it the Canadian who can go to a hospital or a doctor's office and get immediate treatment without fear of financial ruin, or is it the Americans that have to negotiate with an insurance company for coverage they hope they can afford, wait for a few available low-standard spaces in public facilities or face financial ruin?
George Bush has joined an organized U.S. attack on our system by insurance companies, organized medicine and private hospitals because they want to maintain the U.S. system in order to maintain their high profits. They do not like the Canadian system because it is successful and is a powerful example to Americans.
I want to congratulate the Minister of National Health and Welfare for responding to these ill-advised attacks. However, he will truly defend Canadian medicare when he reverses the $64 billion in spending cuts his government has targeted.

Hundreds of seniors in my riding and across Canada have a message for the Prime Minister's 75-cent cost of living increase in their monthly pension cheques: Thanks a whole lot for nothing.

Seniors are calling my riding office saying this increase is a slap in the face and is quite insulting. Does the Prime Minister not realize that 75 cents will not buy a litre of milk or a loaf of bread any more? Does he not realize that 75 cents hardly covers the cost of a $10 purchase?
Why doesn't the Prime Minister or his Minister of National Health and Welfare remove the partial deindexation on seniors' pensions and remember that living on tea and toast may not be a problem for some seniors, but it is reality for thousands of others in this country. Madam Speaker, I would like to draw the attention of the House to the fact that this week is designated White Cane Week. Organized and promoted by the Canadian National Institute for the Blind, the purpose of the week is to make all Canadians aware of the very special challenges faced by blind and visually impaired persons in our society.
The first White Cane Week grew out of the experiences of a small group of blind people who had discovered that the public generally did not understand the meaning of the white cane as a symbol of blindness. That was in 1946. Every year since then, the first week of February has been dedicated to White Cane Week.
This year's theme for White Cane Week is access to information. It is important that the public understand that blindness and severe visual impairment represent a major depravation of information about the environment that affects many aspects of daily life, including reading a newspaper, managing your home and travelling in your neighbourhood.
The CNIB and volunteers are to be congratulated for their contribution and commitment.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance. After remaining at an unacceptably high level of 10.3 per cent for three months in a row, today we learn that unemployment actually increased in January to 10.4 per cent. This means that 70,000 more people were looking for work in January than at the same time last year.
I want to ask the minister this: If his economic policies are the right ones, why is unemployment going up and
not down? If those policies are so great, where is the recovery?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, of course I am deeply concerned about the increase in the unemployment levels. It is a modest increase in unemployment. However, I recognize the serious difficulties that this imposes upon all Canadians but particularly those who are looking for jobs.
As I have said before, there are no quick fixes to the problems we face. It is part of a world-wide situation. Growth in the industrialized countries has faltered, particularly in the United States. We are endeavouring to put in place the fundamentals that will provide for sustained growth and price stability. In the meantime, we are attempting to look at specific sectors that require attention, such as the agricultural industry.
I remind the hon. member that in this fiscal year we put $5.8 billion into the agricultural sector; transportation, which is experiencing serious difficulties, received a $200 million package; the de Havilland assistance package that was put together with the co-operation of the Government of Ontario; the equalization changes which will also help the less wealthy provinces. We are attempting to address the serious sectoral difficulties within our fiscal means. That is the policy of the government.

Madam Speaker, the minister compares us with the United States. Why does he not recognize that our unemployment rate is much, much higher than that of the United States and due to the policies of this government. Those policies are creating misery and not recovery for thousands of Canadians. The government's policies are not working and that is why Canadians are not working either.
A few days ago we learned that the help wanted index was down. We learned that bankruptcies last year were at record levels. Thousands of people are losing their jobs through plant and store closings and lay-offs. Every day we learn of another one. The figures out today do not even begin to take into account the thousands of jobs to be lost in the lay-offs at places like Esso and the Stone Paper Mill in New Brunswick that were announced just earlier this week.
February 7, 1992

I ask the minister: Does this not prove we need an urgent economic recovery plan beyond anything the government has done so far? I ask the minister and the government to come to their senses and put into effect a new total economic recovery plan without any further delay.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member will recognize that the adjustment process, the restructuring that the Canadian industry is undergoing, the downsizing, the consolidation, the changes in the way in which the industrial sector is doing business in order to improve their competitive position is really one of the pressures that has added to the difficulties of the recession.
While the hon. member suggests that the United States has a better unemployment rate, I remind him that at the same time I think he will find that our participation rate in the labour force is higher than the United States. As well, I should point out that notwithstanding the fact that the help wanted index has not improved, I am informed that 76 occupations accounting for 23 per cent of total employment experienced annual growth rates above 2 per cent between 1989 and 1991 and 18 occupations accounting for 3.7 per cent of the total employment experienced annual growth rates above 4 per cent during this period.
What that tells me is that it is important to engage in the skills upgrading, the training programs and the retraining programs. That is why we are increasing that training budget from $3.1 billion to $3.4 billion and the labour development program from $1.4 billion to $1.8 billion. Those are important elements that will address this difficulty to which the hon. member refers.

Madam Speaker, the minister in his answer talks of the economy downsizing. Canadians say that the economy should not be downsizing; it should be growing. With answers like that the government's rate of support in the public opinion polls is soon going to be below the rate of unemployment. It is probably there already.
Oral Questions

Madam Speaker, the unemployment rate is still rising and soon it will pass the government's share of support in the polls. Canadians are looking for work and they need more action from the government.
When will the minister present a new total action plan for a real economic recovery?

Madam Speaker, I do not want to be indifferent to the hon. member but, in fairness, nine years ago when he was over here on the Treasury benches the unemployment rate in Canada was 12.6 per cent and he certainly was not pushing the panic button then. That was certainly too high then and 10.4 is too high today.
As I indicated to him, I am in the process of completing my pre-budget consultations. I have met and discussed the economic situation widely with Canadians across the country. We will be meeting with the premiers. I have met with the finance ministers. I can assure the hon. member that any realistic suggestion that is advanced will be considered. But I have to remind the hon. member that we cannot exceed in a dramatic way our fiscal targets and we cannot consider borrowing our way out of this difficulty. Nor can we consider the option of taxing our way out of this difficulty.

My colleague, the Minister of Communications, announced a program to support the book publishing industry. My colleague from Newfoundland, the minister of fisheries, announced a Newfoundland roads agreement the other day.

February 7, 1992

lower our deficit. You cannot spend your way out of the recession". Mr. Harcourt said that, and I agree.

Madam Speaker, of course we will listen and we will do whatever we can afford to do that will be helpful.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have this opportunity to rise on behalf of my colleague, the Minister for Science who has an unavoidable previous commitment, to make reference to the announcement on Wednesday in the media that a major breakthrough had been made in the study of the most common form of muscular dystrophy, myotonic dystrophy.
Hon. members may be aware that this debilitating disease affects the muscles but can also involve the eyes, heart, lungs or digestive system. In Canada about one person in 7,000 suffers from this disease, but in some areas the incidence runs as high as one in 500.
The Canadian Genetic Diseases Network announced that Dr. Robert Korneluk of the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario, one of the network's 23 principal investigators, has isolated the genetic defect responsible for the myotonic dystrophy. This is the latest in a series of genetic discoveries in Canada. The cystic fibrosis gene was discovered by another member of the network. The muscular dystrophy gene was discovered by Dr. Ronald Worton.
I would like to point out to the House that each of these researchers is a member of the Canadian Genetic Diseases Network. Since the network was created in 1989 as part of the networks of centres of excellence program it has quickly demonstrated the effectiveness of national collaboration in fostering scientific research.

Since last year the network's program has been funded to the rate of $450,000 over the next five years for Dr. Korneluk's research. As my colleague, the hon. member for Calgary Southwest pointed out yesterday, another $400,000 in funding was also provided by the Medical Research Council, which is Canada's major agency funding medical research.
The Muscular Dystrophy Association of Canada and its United States counterparts as well as the Research Institute of the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario and the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Auxiliary contributed to the research.
Madam Speaker, you know the alliances, the partnerships and the collaborations that are key to scientific research both in Canada and around the world. Dr. Korneluk worked with colleagues in the United States, Netherlands and Great Britain in isolating the gene. On behalf of the Government of Canada I would like to congratulate Dr. Korneluk and his colleagues.
I would also like to thank the 165 families in the Ottawa area who participated in Dr. Korneluk's research. This was the largest group of families affected by myotonic dystrophy ever to be studied. I know that these families and many more across Canada and around the world will take heart from this discovery.
In the short term it is going to mean more rapid diagnosis of myotonic dystrophy. In the long term it may mean new breakthroughs in ways to treat the disease.
In addition, the discovery will help advance the course of science in Canada, science that is not only key to Canada's prosperity but is also helping Canadians to live healthier lives.

Madam Speaker, it is with great pleasure that I rise to offer congratulations to those who have isolated the genetic defect responsible for myotonic muscular dystrophy.
This landmark breakthrough was made here in Ottawa by Dr. Robert Korneluk and a research team at the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario.
As we all know, muscular dystrophy is a tragic disease. Myotonic dystrophy is the most common form affecting adults. Its symptoms are progressive weakness and myotonia, which is an inability to relax muscles after they have contracted.
Routine Proceedings
At this time there is no treatment for this form of muscular dystrophy. All that can be provided is physical therapy and medication to help muscles relax. This discovery will mean dramatically improved diagnosis. Most important, doctors will be better able to advise parents who come from families with a history of the disease so they will know whether they risk passing on this genetic defect.
Of course the discovery raises our hopes that we are much closer to finding a treatment or cure for this disease.
Madam Speaker, it often seems in this House that we have a lot of problems to address, a lot of negative issues to deal with. In a world where things so often go wrong, these medical advances seem nothing less than a miracle.
It is one of those times when members of the scientific research community, who spend so many years of their lives in often frustrating research, are publicly recognized for their great efforts.
Again, on behalf of the Liberal Party and all the families and victims of this disease, my congratulations to all those involved in this breakthrough.

speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
In total the government reduced 23,542 person-years from the Public Service over the five years between 1985-86 and 1990-91. This represented a reduction of approximately 10 per cent of the adjusted 1985-86 authorized person-year levels (see Note 1). From this amount, 11,165 person-years were reallocated to respond to new priorities and to maintain critical service levels related to health, safety and security. The net result was that there were 12,377 fewer person-years authorized in the 1990-91 Main Estimates than in 1985-86.
Note 1: Over the years the Treasury Board has approved a number of adjustments to its policy on person-year controls, which had the effect of eliminating such controls over specific organizations or particular groups or classes of employee. To ensure a consistent comparison, the analysis above adjusts the authorized person-year levels originally reported in all years including the base year to reflect any changes in the size of the Treasury Board person-year controlled universe.
2. (i) The Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development was reduced by 2,143 person-years from its 1985-86 base level of 6,245 to its 1990-91 level of 4,102.
(ii) Of the total departmental reduction of 2,143 person-years 1,370 is attributable to the transfer of program funds and responsibilities to First Nations and their organizations. The other person-year reductions resulted from transfers of program funds and responsibilities to the territorial governments and from efficiency gains made throughout the department.

subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as I was saying about this bill on double taxation, my concern is that there is no taxation.
What the hon. member for Bonavista-Trinity-Conception just tried to move in this House regarding an emergency debate on Hibernia relates to this bill because Gulf Canada decided to pull out of Hibernia in Canada and to go ahead with an investment in Siberia.
Petro-Canada, our great national oil company put in place by the taxpayers of Canada, recently announced the closure of gas stations across Canada. It is an enormous cutback. At the same time Petro-Canada is investing in an oil development in Burma.
The bill we have before us today relates to agreements concerning income tax. Income tax was introduced in this country on the basis of progressive taxation. The term income tax as it emerged in Canada during the First
Government Orders
World War was demanded by the farmers of western Canada and the workers of eastern Canada. It was demanded by the people. It is the only tax I know of that was demanded by the people of Canada, as it was demanded by the people of the United States before 1900. It was based on the fact that when you say "income tax" it means a tax on income. We have a system that says to Gulf Canada that it can pull out of a development in Canada and go into a development in Siberia and deduct from its taxable income in Canada every cent of money it is spending in Siberia.
The government says to Petro-Canada: "You can pull out of operations in Canada and lay off people in 1,700 service stations, get that pool of money, go ahead with your investment in Burma and every cent, to the penny, the hundreds of millions of dollars, you can get it all back because you can subtract it from your taxable income in Canada for this year, next year, next year, for the year after and the year after until you get it all back. If you have $100,000 of taxable income this year in Canada, you can take $100,000 off that billion you are spending in Burma and you pay no taxes".
What kind of a system is this at this time of recession, at this time of saying to ordinary Canadians: "Tighten your belt. Pay new taxes". Talk about double taxation. Ordinary Canadians are paying triple taxation. However, the government says to the oil companies: "If you do not want to pay any taxes, if you do not want to pay any income tax, invest in Siberia, invest in Burma. Pull out of Newfoundland, pull out of your gas stations".
At times to use the income tax system to promote a development is not a bad thing; it is a good thing. Whether or not it was good or bad or justified that this government initially approved a tax write-off for the purchase of Gulf Canada in the beginning is debatable. I seriously doubt it, when a tax concession of $500 million was approved for a company that has $7 billion in assets. But that is what was done.
As the minister said in the House yesterday, that was called the Little Egypt Bump. We can call this movement of Gulf the Siberian shove because it has decided to invest in Siberia and pull out of its development off the coast of Newfoundland.
Perhaps the time has come for the Government of Canada to step back a little bit and look at all of these

Government Orders
taxation agreements and look at the income tax system as it relates to the companies covered in these agreements so that the encouragement is there for them to invest in this country and not to use the money they are saving in Canada to invest in a foreign nation and have the taxpayers of Canada foot the bill.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am not sure exactly how my hon. friend's remarks relate to tax treaties between Finland, Czechoslovakia, Mexico and our own country. However, since his comments evidently fall within the scope of the debate I do want to say that while he talks on the surface of double taxation I think what he provides to a certain extent is double-talk.
I am not sure whether it is the policy of his party that the Government of Canada should direct people who are in business on how to do their business, or whether these businesses should be free to try to operate on a basis that makes it worth while for them. It is my understanding that most businesses are in business to make money and to do those things that make sound business sense.
With respect to the issue of taxation, my hon. friend points out that there are deductions for business expenses against income tax. I think the point he should make is that those deductions apply whether those investments are in Canada or abroad.
What he fails to do is go the next step, as the minister did earlier today, and point out that they are taxed on the profits or indeed the income that results from those business investments. At one point he seemed to imply that there should be different standards for taxation applied to different companies or indeed different taxpayers.
I would like to ask him first: Does he believe that the same standards of taxation should apply to all taxpayers in Canada or should there be different rules for different taxpayers? Second, does he believe in the notion that there should be deductions before the determination of tax rates to be paid by taxpayers, and does he disagree with the notion that Canadians or Canadian companies should be taxed on profits they accrue from overseas revenues?

subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I shall tiy to answer each one of these questions in the order in which they were put.
First of all, he mentioned the profits that are taxed in foreign nations. I remind the hon. member and the Minister for National Revenue that the foreign exploration and development deductions on the income tax returns of these oil companies allow them to deduct 10 per cent each year-it does go down to 9.6 per cent in the second year in the case of Gulf-of their total amount of exploration and development expenses. But it also allows them to deduct from their taxable income in Canada 100 per cent of their profits from their oil development in Siberia.
That is the system that is in effect in our income tax for companies which invest in foreign nations, so do not talk to me about profits in foreign nations. The higher the profit, the bigger deduction they have from their taxable income in Canada.
Now that I have explained that, let me move to the second point. Should there be, he says, deductions before income tax is paid. Of course there should be deductions. But there is not a Canadian who agrees with a system that says that those deductions can be used not only to totally evade taxes but also to allow somebody making a quarter of a million dollars a year in this country to claim benefits that are due to low and modest income people. Nobody in this country agrees with somebody making over $100,000 a year and being able to claim the child tax credit as they do when the maximum you can make is $26,500 to get the child tax credit and then it goes down. The deductions, the business losses, the RSPs; there are 11 deductions before your net income is arrived at and your net income is used to determine every single income tested benefit under the tax system: The child tax credit, GST rebate, federal sales tax rebate, name them all.
Now the next question: Should there be the same standards of taxation for everybody? There should be a standard. The standard of taxation was arrived at, at the turn of this century, by a Tory government by the way. In 1917 that government wanted conscription in Canada and the farmers were demanding income taxes because there were some wealthy families in two cities in this country that were importing cars from Europe.
February 7, 1992

They demanded fair taxation because all we had was a commodity tax that, as you know, placed an unfair burden on ordinary people because they used the majority of their income just to live.
For example, lower income people have to spend all that money on the GST so they pay a greater percentage in GST. Somebody making $200,000 a year can put money into RRSPs, investments. The percentage spent on the GST is lower.
When the income tax system came into this country, brought in by a Tory government, it did not want to bring it in. It wanted conscription because we were in a war. Its members met in the back rooms of this Chamber with the Liberal opposition. The Liberals said: "We will vote for conscription if you agree to bring in an income tax based on a person's income. It should be progressive. The higher the amount of money you make, the greater percentage you pay in taxes".
That is how income tax began in Canada. If you go back, that is how it began in the United States. It was a demand of the people. It went to the Supreme Court of the U.S. and was judged unconstitutional. The judges said: "How could the majority impose a system of taxation on the minority" who were the rich. The Constitution had to be changed to make it legal.
Do I believe in the same standards of taxes for everyone? Yes, I certainly do. The unfortunate part of it is that over the years since we brought in income taxes, there has been one group of people in this country who do not pay any income taxes at all. The hon. member knows that number is rising. Statistics for last year show that there are many hundreds of people making over $250,000 total income who pay not one penny of income tax, not a single penny.
Do I believe in a standard of taxes for everyone? Sure I do. I believe in the standard that was brought in when the income tax system was set up in this country during the First World War, a system that has not been followed. It is a system that now has got to this bill that we are passing here today, this agreement with these foreign nations that has as its base our own income tax system which says that if you are Gulf Canada you can invest in Siberia and get the same tax benefits as if you invested in Canada.
Government Orders
You get 100 per cent of it deducted. It says to Petro-Canada: "You can close service stations. Invest in Burma". That country does not exactly have a good record on human rights, does it? "Invest there and you get the same benefits as if you invested in Canada".
In fact, when you really examine the taxation systems that are in effect in those nations, you will discover that it is to the company's benefit to invest in those countries and not to invest in Canada. That is why I say that the government has to rethink this whole system because Canadians are sick and tired of being told that they have to tighten their belts and pay more taxes. They can see that these companies are paying nothing and they are living off the taxpayers of Canada while they invest in foreign nations.

subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I first of all want to say how impressed I am with the previous speaker's analysis of what is taking place. Frankly his scope of bringing the whole double taxation question into a very important bill is important in this House.
Tragically the framework within this bill has been defined in a sense of time by one of the government spokespersons. This goes back to 1971.1 do not intend to do Liberal government bashing. What we knew in 1971 and what we knew 15 years ago when we started these discussions, and it is relevant to provincial governments as well, is entirely different from what we know today.
My good friend has pointed out, by case, what we know today that we did not know in 1971 when this opening was allowed. My good friend has pointed that out in case what we know now applies to Mexico did not apply then as well.
In a world that is being described as the new global economy, we are framing legislation in this bill that is in a world which no longer exists. We think that by sector by sector agreements, for instance with the Mexican government, we are protecting our turf. We also understand, and my friend through his illustration gave proof to this, that money moves within seconds internationally. Money can move from Zurich, from Tokyo, from Hong Kong, from Toronto, from Washington and from London at the press of a computer button. That did not exist in 1971 and I am not going to blame the Liberal govern-

Government Orders
ment for giving this loophole. That did not exist 15 years ago when my friend talked about the attempt to get a deal. It exists now.
While we politicians sometimes are trapped in classic debates about you said this and you did that, our classic debates are no longer relevant to the technological changes and trade changes that have taken place in this country and in the world.
No one would deliberately set out to allow Gulf to get away with what it did. Gulf got away with it. There has been no clear leadership from this government, as my colleague has clearly pointed out, to close this loophole. This bill will not close the loophole for Mexico or for anyone else.
The appeal is being made by those of us who are reading this and beginning to understand the rapidly changing global world economy. We are elected in Canada, and I am not talking about supemationalism; I am talking about basic political responsibility to the taxpayers of this country. Our basic responsibility is to take as a base line the question of what we need to protect here in Canada as the people who sit on the other side of the table say: "What is it we need here to protect in Mexico?"
Frankly I do not assume that the person you sit down with is going to cheat you. I do not assume that anybody is going to distort the facts. Everybody sits at the table in this kind of legislation with the motivation of enlightened self-interest.
I do not think this government has done enough work. I will stick clearly to the relevance that the Chair so wisely suggested to the House and I will only talk about Mexico and the avoidance of double taxation.
Since this particular bill was introduced, we have had placed in our hands information concerning government documents that indicate a profound potential negative effect of the treaty that the United States and Canada are discussing. That profound negative effect in the documents applies to taxation as well. I will be relevant in dealing with that taxation aspect.
In the areas of textiles, auto parts, plastics, and secondary and tertiary manufacturing for basic resources, there will be no clear-cut explanation once this bill is passed of its implication based on an agreement that is being negotiated.
For the wisdom of all the members of this House, for the protection of the Canadian taxpayers, it would be far better if this bill were withdrawn until the House knows exactly what deck the government is dealing from.
What else is there behind the scenes that we have to force out of secret documents? Why is it that the press has to apply for freedom of information on negotiating positions that have major implications on this bill? I am making a plea to this House, neither for nor against this bill but that we simply do not know enough about what is going on behind the scenes to make a rational decision on this bill. We cannot even have an ideological debate, traditionally from the right, the centre or the left on this bill, because the facts are not before us.
I do not think there is any ill intent by the government in pursuing this bill at this time. I just think there was no thought given to the timing of this bill relative to other things that are happening in a rapidly changing global economy.
It would be far better if this bill were withdrawn for about six months. It would be far better if a committee of this House were struck to deal with that specific broad problem in which this bill falls, and that is the changing global economy.
I think it is absolutely essential in this day and age that every parliamentarian be armed with updated information about this rapidly changing world instead of being fixed here in an almost analogous situation of trying to drive a steam tractor when there are already other operations of carbon driven engines. The House is being hampered by being left in a back frame of time that no longer exists.
It does not surprise me that in some instances when I go back to my constituency people ask me: "Why did you vote this way on this bill? Why did you not think of this or that?" We cannot think of everything. In the crunch we ultimately have to make a decision about many things every single day and we do our best in terms of what is humanly possible.
In this instance, our best in terms of what is humanly possible is to put this bill aside until we as parliamentarians have every single known fact available to us, not kept secret, about our changing relationship with Mexico, because this bill deals with double taxation in Mexico.
February 7, 1992

What is that changing relationship going to be in terms of one major area, tariffs and content and taxation around the automobile parts industry? How does this bill apply? What does it mean if we change the content rule, as is being discussed in the Canada-Mexico free trade agreement, to the question of double taxation on a Canadian investor who is an auto parts manufacturer if he decides to close his plant here, move to Mexico, manufacture there, cut himself back into the market, avoid the tariffs, take his money out of Canada and not be taxed at all out of the Mexican operation and still have a piece of the action?
What does it mean? What does it mean to Quebec and its textile industry, or what is left of it? What does it mean to the plastics industry and double taxation? There is not a single sector of secondary or tertiary manufacturing in terms of investment and double taxation that is not impacted by those talks.
I would like to know what the Canadian government position is. I would like to know where we are going. Although we may have a difference of where we are going and how we get there, how can we possibly deal with this bill until we know where the government is going, how it wants to get there and what its bottom line is? This is like giving a licence to a 10-year-old to drive a car so that when he reaches 18 we hope he will know what he is doing. This is certainly putting the cart before the horse.
I ask my friends to seriously consider exactly the kind of situation they are placing the House in. We do not know enough. We simply do not know enough about the implication of this bill and its meaning to those who wish to invest in Canada and who wish to invest in Mexico.
If I were a Mexican investor and I were faced with this legislation, the questions that I would ask about investment back in or joint ventures with Canadians could not be answered at this time.
There is no possible way even with this bill being passed, in the framework of the negotiations that are going on with a whole new change of trading partners, that this bill will have any relevance a year from now or two years from now if we sign the agreement.
Government Orders
I think that this bill just got stuck in the government's house works. Its name appeared on the Order Paper and was presented and the government thought: well, this is just a routine thing; let's get it through. It is not a routine bill, but it got captured in the bureaucracy. It got captured in the structure. It is thrust up in the House at a time when we are incapable of dealing with it.
This is not entirely a partisan appeal. It certainly is not without some partisanship, but beyond the partisan appeal that I am making there is a very real appeal that I am trying to present to the government. That is that this bill now is fraught with potential dangers just down the road, 18 months or 36 months from now.
When we take into consideration my hon. friend's historical analysis of how long it took to get this bill here, he suggested 15 years, once the bill is passed it would probably take another 15 years before we would get around to correcting it.
By that time, we could potentially be losing tens or hundreds of millions of dollars worth of taxes that should be coming back to the Canadian people.
I appeal to this government. If it is looking for items on the agenda of this House to do busy work there is other legislation that is far more advanced in terms of information, far more able to get through this House with a consensus, far more important at this point to deal with current problems than this bill.
This bill would entrench a system of taxation and counter taxation that may not have any relevance with Mexico whatsoever within a year or a year and a half.
I want to come to what a suspicious mind might think about this. Not mine, because I am a trusting soul. A suspicious mind might suggest that the government is rushing this bill through the House knowing in advance what the implications are in terms of double taxation on a treaty that it is negotiating without informing the House of the details of what its negotiating position is. That is what a suspicious mind would raise.
Far be it from me to raise any public suspicion on this government. It is too far down in the polls for me to add to that. But if that suspicious mind were accurate then it would go further to say that the way to get this bill though without controversy is ahead of the Canada-U.S.-Mexico free trade agreement, is ahead of the revelations of exactly what Canada's position is, and

February 7, 1992
Government Orders
ahead of any more release of secret documents as they were today under the aegis of Southam News.
I am the least suspicious member in this House, but I have it as a matter of fact that there are some who are far more suspicious than I am. They seem to have a great deal more experience than I as an ingenue in this Chamber, a somewhat chubby ingenue but an ingenue nonetheless.
I say with all great seriousness, the speaker who spoke before me in his articulate analysis of what Gulf has got away with, in his clear-cut and perfectly in order speech about the implication of those tax avoiders, has raised doubts in my mind that perhaps, to be charitable, this government knows not what it is doing.
But perhaps my colleague who spoke before has a suspicion that indeed it knows what it is doing, that indeed its friends who may supply campaign funds are anxious to see this kind of legislation. There are some sceptics in this country that actually believe the old axiom that Canada gets the best politicians that money can buy. I do not know if that is the kind of political science law that is being taught, but the nasty haste around this bill makes even an ingenue like me suspicious.
On this quiet Friday we will gently get this bill through. Not to worry about the changing dramatics of the Canada-U.S.-Mexico free trade agreement, not to worry about the implications of what Gulf has already got away with in Hibernia, not to focus on Siberia, as my good friend has used as an apt example in terms of this legislation and Mexico, but to quietly get this through so that those who will benefit are well protected before the t's are crossed and the i's are dotted under the Canada-U.S.-Mexico agreement.
My appeal is not made on partisanship, as much as I always love to appeal on partisanship. My appeal is made on common sense of which there is an absence of a great deal in this House.
Why the rush? Pull the bill. Let us find out all the facts before we are asked to vote. Otherwise, and I do not say this as a threat, I will be forced to publicly say that the assessment of my friend in the Liberal Party is absolutely correct. This is another bill to cover another sell out of Canadian taxpayers' interests.
It has nothing to do with Liberal ideology, nothing to do with the NDP and its philosophical position, nothing
to do with the government's philosophical position. But it has everything to do with paying off the wealthy corporations that have used loopholes in this country time and time again to escape their fair share of taxes.
Fairness is what this is all about and fairness we must have. To be decent in attempting to reach that fairness, I ask the government to pull this bill off the floor. I know that after I have made this appeal it will immediately do so.
