speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to begin by complimenting my hon. friend opposite for the skilful manner in which I believe he tied his remarks to the subject on the floor, unlike some previous speakers.
I heard him say earlier that he had been a parliamentarian for 25 years and I thought he was very skilful in doing that.
However, I would like to remind the hon. member he suggested the bill should be pulled. I notice he made no identification, at least I did not hear him identify any flaws in any of the three treaties or the convention. He does not seem to have any difficulty with them.
He is suggesting that we should hold up the implementation of this bill, one element of which for example provides an opportunity for Revenue Canada, and indeed for its counterpart in Mexico, to exchange information to chase down tax evaders.
I assume that he would agree with the government that catching up with tax evaders is an extremely important thing and that we should do that.
I would remind him as well that right now there are 50 tax treaties virtually the same as these in force between Canada and various countries in the world. I would be glad to share with him a list of those countries.
I would remind him that we are in negotiation with 26 countries of the world to put together similar tax treaties. When we bring forward this bill, it would put in force three further tax treaties that have been signed but not yet put in force by legislation. That is what this bill is about.
This bill has nothing to do whatsoever, with all due respect, with trade negotiations between Canada and Mexico. It has to do with fulfilling the implications of the income tax revisions of 1971, putting together a system which makes it possible for Canadians to participate in
February 7, 1992

business and to do investments and not to be subjected to double taxation. That is what this bill is about.
It is not about Canada-Mexico free trade. I am wondering why my hon. friend is not expressing the same amount of concern about having tax treaties with the other 50 countries that we have them with or indeed with the 26 other countries that we are now negotiating with.
I would respectfully suggest and I would ask him therefore if he would identify specifically the flaws in the three treaties and the information exchange convention now before this House. If there are indeed flaws there, I wish he would identify them and bring them forth.
Otherwise I see no relevance whatsoever to his suggestion, which I know he puts in the best of faith, that we should withdraw this bill for six months.

subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the member for his expression of closely held beliefs. On a Friday, to dispel myths for such an earnest speaker I do with difficulty. Since I am challenged to do it, I must do it.
My good friend suggests that this is a simple bill to avoid double taxation, that we have agreements with 50 other countries already, none of which is sitting down at the table changing the rules as Mexico is right now. Why not wait until we have decided what rule changes take place before we pass this?
Let me give one simple example to my friend, simply put so it is simply understood. If you, under this bill, intend to move your auto parts manufacturing to Mexico and this bill is enforced, what will happen is that existing rules under this bill will pursue your personal profits for taxation.
I put this to you on the belief that everybody is playing fair and square. My friend who spoke from the Liberal Party suggests that Gulf is playing within the rules, but are the rules fair and square?
The example I want to give is that rules of origin identify ultimately where a product is made and traced back and taxation is made based on rules of origin.
After we signed the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement we had to be vigilant about rules of origin. I raised
Government Orders
that question with the minister at that time. He said that we are making massive attempts to tighten up because of the change in the agreement. I said: "What have you done?" He said: "We have hired six more customs inspectors".
Cross-border shopping takes 106 more customs inspectors, let alone rules of origin. What is the impact of this when we sign the Canada-Mexico agreement?
The rules of origin are still flaunted. Some of the parts manufactured in Mexico today are unidentified. They are shipped across the border under the Maquiladora program. They are incorporated into American parts. That whole part is identified. That is shipped into Canada.
The only area of taxation that exists between Mexico and Canada now is eliminated because of the Canada-U.S. FTA and they are companies sending in subparts without identity and avoiding taxation to the Canadian taxpayer.
It is estimated that with that one loophole $3 billion is lost to the taxpayers of this country. Do you know what $3 billion would do if we close that loophole? A lot of jobs.
I did not mean to be harsh. I do not mean to punish this government. But when it displays such stupidity and then at times to compound it with ignorance, then it is far too much for me to take and my gentleness disappears.
By giving that one example I am trying to point out that we should not burden the Canadian taxpayers with further loopholes, unless we know exactly the kind of situation we are getting into with Mexico.
The government cannot say it today. It cannot even announce it today. The press has to pick out information that was secret. My questions were not even answered. My sensitivities were insulted for a week.
On top of that we have this bill. We are going to get hosed again. That is not good enough; it is simply not good enough.
I must now make a comment that I did not intend to make. This is a government that says it is businesslike. Businesslike administration run by businessmen, and I add for businessmen, by an astute, thoughtful group of

Government Orders
politicians. You do not even know when they are trying to sell you the Brooklyn Bridge.
This thing is full of loopholes, particularly when you do not even know yourself or cannot even say publicly what kind of agreement you are going to sign with Mexico.
Do not appeal to me with the idea of shells. Which shell is the pea under? In this shell game we have three shells and no peas under any one of them. We are being asked to sign it.
Just look at the rules of origin as they exist now and see the loopholes that exist. Pass this, and there will be loopholes to drive VIA trains through, that is the ones that are still running.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is with a great deal of pleasure that I follow the very thoughtful remarks of my hon. colleague from Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca who has laid out very, very clearly what is actually happening here today.
For those who might be watching this presentation this afternoon on a Friday in the House of Commons, I want to remind people that we are dealing with a bill that originated in the Senate, a bill called S-2. Its title is: "an act to implement conventions between Canada and Finland, Canada and the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic and Canada and the United Mexican States for the avoidance of double taxation with respect to income tax and the prevention of fiscal evasion and a convention between Canada and the United Mexican States for the exchange of information with respect to taxes".
There is an old myth around this place that if the government has something it wants to slip through, or if it has an announcement it wants to make and it wants to get as little public recognition as possible, the time to do it is late on a Friday. Late on a Friday is when the press gallery wraps up its affairs for the week and people's attention turns to items other than what is going on in the Parliament of Canada. It is a long-standing tradition that this is the way to low-ball data and information, this is the way to minimize public attention.
We were looking at the legislation in the last few days and we noticed this rather innocuous looking bill, Bill S-2, to establish taxation conventions between a number of countries. As everybody knows, Canada now has tax treaties with 50 different nations. Over the last number
of months we have been negotiating six more tax agreements and there are still 26 outstanding for future negotiations.
It is not a surprise that we do this on a regular basis. We negotiate these tax arrangements to facilitate business between countries. In looking at the bill, Mr. Speaker, you will notice that, yes, it deals with Finland. There are certainly no difficulties there. It deals with Czechoslovakia, again there are no particular difficulties there. Then you start looking at some of the fine details.
When it comes to Mexico it says that it deals with factories, workshops, offices, branch plants, the development of natural resources and tax issues, of course, related to those. It deals with income from immovable property and business profits. It involves shipping and air transport taxation. It involves associated enterprises and the taxation thereof. It involves dividends and how they are dealt with, interest payments and how they are dealt with, royalties and how they are dealt with, personal services and how they are going to be taxed, capital gains, and the matter of apprentices and the taxation surrounding apprenticeships.' It goes on and on.
We noticed that these would be of serious concern to those individuals wanting to do business in Mexico, to those corporations presently involved in the free trade zone in northern Mexico and the migration of many branch plants, American branch plants and others in Canada, to that free trade zone in Mexico in anticipation of the Canada-U.S.-Mexico free trade agreement being signed in the next few weeks.
Here we are then. We are asked to approve today a special taxation arrangement with Mexico while we all know that we are negotiating a free trade deal with Mexico at the same time. Those of us in the New Democratic Party think that this is folly. This is something we ought not to be doing, period.
We know what happened to Canada when we negotiated a free trade deal with the United States. We got hosed. At last count, if memory serves me, 500,000 jobs in the manufacturing sector have disappeared in Canada, largely because of the implications of the Canada-U.S. trade agreement. Many have been very up front. After all, we recognize that corporations exist to do business and maximize their profits for their shareholders.
February 7, 1992

They have announced day after day that they are closing down the Canadian operation and moving to Tennessee, Florida, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama to take advantage of lower wages, more lax health and safety regulations, and softer environmental regulations. In other words, it is a lot cheaper because a great deal more exploitation can be conducted.
As we enter into a free trade agreement with Mexico, we have concerns about the implications. What does it mean for Canada? What will happen to Canadian businesses? How will it assist us? What will be the cost? Of course, we do not know because all the negotiations are being done in secret. They are being done behind closed doors.
Today in the newspaper it said: "Secret papers show Canada to get less than it bargains for in the Canada-Mexico trade negotiations".
Another headline says: "The pact would cost jobs, government papers indicate". What government papers are these? Earlier today my hon. colleague from Esquimau-Juan de Fuca asked the Minister for International Trade that considering senators from Mexico's parliament have had access to the documents being negotiated and have had the benefit of direct briefings and selected congressmen in the United States have had access to the agreement being discussed and have had intensive and extensive briefings, why have the parliamentarians of Canada and thereby the people of Canada been kept in the dark and have no idea what the negotiations are all about?
We read, presumably from papers that the Americans and Mexicans have seen, that jobs in the textile industries of Canada would be lost to a significant degree, that jobs in the footwear sector would be hammered mercilessly. As for agriculture, it says that grain growers, livestock producers, pork producers, and oilseed growers will have some problems. It also says there will be a massive shift of the auto parts and automobile industry to Mexico, particularly the free trade zones, from both Canada and the U.S. In other words, just a cursory glance at what is in those documents-

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
May I just ask the hon. member if he is reading from the bill or from some other notes? I am just trying to figure out why we are
Government Orders
discussing free trade in terms of this particular bill. It concerns double taxation and property and development more than anything else. I do not see free trade in there and I would just like to know from where the hon. member is getting his information, other than out of this Bill S-2.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I understand the concern. First,
I was getting my information from American and Mexican excerpts, presumably from the secret free trade agreements which we have not seen but they have, as reported in today's papers.
Mr. Speaker, you ask about the relevancy of quoting from these secret papers that we have not seen. It is because Bill S-2 deals with double taxation, and double taxation occurs when Canadian firms do business in Mexico or Mexican firms do business in Canada. The free trade agreement is all about enhancing the amount of interaction between our two countries.
If we are negotiating a free trade agreement to expand and facilitate business activity between two countries and are debating today the taxation implications, the linkage does not seem to be particularly vague to me. As a matter of fact, it seems to be perfectly clear. That is why my hon. friend from Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca said this is out of step. speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
My hon. colleague rightfully points out, and I think it is a very thoughtful intervention, that we do not have free trade agreements with some of the other countries we have entered into tax negotiations with, particularly Norway, Malta, Thailand, Spain, Singapore, Romania and others. He is absolutely correct. That is why I would propose to facilitate the taxation negotiations taking place and the signatures now required for Finland and the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic. I think we should do this expeditiously. After all, that is straightforward.
However, let us be cautious. After all, the third part of this bill deals with Mexico. I have indicated some of the

February 7, 1992
Government Orders
areas in which it deals with trade with Mexico: shipping and air transport, dividends, royalties, property, profits, workshops, branch plants and natural resource development. In other words, this seems to have serious implications for what we are apparently negotiating with Mexico and the United States.
I would suggest that a prudent approach would be to agree to proceed with parts I and II of this legislation, dealing with Finland and the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic, and set aside part m, dealing with Canada and the United Mexican States, until we see what this free trade agreement is going to mean for Canada.
I think it is fair to say that anyone who would speak honestly would say that the benefits of the Canada-U.S. agreement are difficult to find. I am not going to say that there are absolutely none. I do not think that would be fair. Obviously there have been some Canadian firms and Canadian workers who have benefited from access to the United States markets when there might have been more difficulties in past times.
I would suggest that for every job we have gained we probably have lost 100 jobs. I will give one example. My hon. colleague looks puzzled. Just the other day the response to an Order Paper question showed that there are thousands and thousands of Americans who have now used chapter fifteen of the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement to access Canada who normally would not have been here pursuing those jobs which would be filled by Canadian workers. The free trade agreement has made it a lot easier for skilled tradesmen from the United States and professionals from the United States to do business in Canada.

subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: And vice versa.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Technically vice versa, yes. My hon. friend will also know that there are a number of hurdles in the United States that make it much more difficult for Canadians to do business there than for Americans to do business in Canada. Somewhere between 40 and 100 per cent, depending on what sector you look at, is foreign owned in Canada as opposed to a foreign ownership of 4 per cent of the United States' economy. Naturally there are a lot more Americans doing business in Canada on an ongoing basis because they own such a large part of
Canada. The free trade agreement simply made it easier for them to operate.
We all know that. That is on the table. We all understand that. Some want to continue. Others want to abrogate the free trade deal and get on with developing our own bilateral relations with the United States in terms of trade. However, the reality is that, although we in Canada know nothing about it because we are being kept in the dark, a trade deal is being negotiated between Canada and Mexico.
Our Mexican colleagues know about it, our American colleagues know about it, but parliamentarians in Canada have to rely on our American and Mexican friends in order to get any information. This is wrong. That is why I say it is also wrong to proceed today with this legislation to harmonize the tax laws between Canada and the United Mexican States to facilitate economic development between the two countries. It is misguided to proceed. I have yet to hear a good reason why we ought to proceed with this part of the bill.
I would urge the government members to give consideration to splitting. As it stands, I regretfully have to say that our party, the New Democratic Party, is not able to support this legislation in its present form. If it was to be split so that we can facilitate our agreements with Finland and the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic certainly we would endorse that.
Let us not put the cart before the horse. Let us not sign a taxation agreement with Mexico until we see what is in this free trade agreement with Mexico and whether we are going to benefit in Canada or be net losers as we are under the Canada-U.S. FTA.

subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker,
I have a question for my colleague concerning the issue of double taxation. Right now double taxation is an inhibitor to Canadian companies moving down to Mexico, while other things might be more attractive. For example, in a recent news item I saw that Green Giant Foods, located in Texas, was paying its workers wages of $7 an hour. A worker for Green Giant would go to the plant and make $56 a day canning produce or processing food.

Then Green Giant suddenly closed its plant in Texas, I believe it was, or Arizona, and moved across the border into Mexico where it was paying its workers $4.80 a day.
Think of that: wages of $56 a day being paid in the United States, and that company moved almost within sight of the original plant, across the border into Mexico, and was paying its Mexican workers $4.80 a day. The savings in wages was something like 90 per cent over what it was paying its American workers.
The same thing would apply in Canada if a Canadian plant were moved to the United States. It would be saving something like 90 per cent of its wage bills.
Nobody saw the can of Green Giant corn go down in price by 90 per cent. There was no benefit to the consumers. All of that money went to additional profit for the processing company.
If we had the current tax regime as exists between Canada and Mexico, Canada would be able to tax that whole 90 per cent increase in profit which that company gained as a result of the lower wages in Mexico. Canada would be able to pay, for example, for adjustment programs, for unemployment insurance programs for the workers who were put out of work in Canada. Under this piece of legislation, the government not only wants to give those jobs to the Mexicans, the investment to the Mexicans, and the profit to that company, but it also wants to give it a tax credit. It wants to give that company a tax credit for the tax it pays in Mexico.
Canada loses out on all counts. I have not heard anything in the government's position in this debate today that Canada is going to gain anything from this piece of legislation in conjunction with the Mexican free trade legislation.
I would like my colleague to elaborate on that. Should we be giving jobs from highly paid Canadian plants to Mexico, where they make one-tenth in wages of what they make here, and allow the profits to increase accordingly for that company for moving from Canada to Mexico? Not only that, but based on this legislation, should we make sure that the Mexican government gets to collect the taxes and we give the company credit for the taxes that it pays in Mexico?
Government Orders
What a bunch of losers. They are creating a situation for themselves in which Canadians lose on all counts. I appreciate the speech that my colleague from Kamloops made and hopefully he can elaborate on that.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not believe there is much to elaborate upon when I listen to the point made by my hon. colleague. He paints a puzzling picture.
I will simply elaborate on the most recent statistics I have seen in terms of manufacturing wage rates. Consider a situation in which a person who had $20 million at his disposal and wished to begin a manufacturing line. He wanted to start a new plant to manufacture some product. You have three choices under our Canada-U.S.-Mexico free trade deal. You can locate your plant in Canada and you would pay your employees on the average between $10 and $15 an hour, or you could move to the southern United States and open in South Carolina, Alabama, in Mississippi or in Louisiana, and you would be paying on the average between $6 and $8 an hour, or you could go over the line into the northern tier of Mexico and pay between $24 and $28 a week.
Unless you were insane, where would you be tempted to locate your plant if labour were an important criterion in your operation? Obviously, if it were power, if there were some other elements, you might be encouraged to locate elsewhere in the North American context. Labour is critical and we see it in the news today. That is why the American congressmen and the Mexican senators are saying that the businesses in Canada, particularly in the auto industry, the auto parts industry, the textile industry, the footwear industry and in agricultural processing, had better be careful.
You could open a factory or a plant in Mexico and pay people $24 to $28 per week for labour. That is working six days a week, I might add, with virtually no environmental, health and safety laws being enforced and virtually no labour regulations enforced. That is what we are seeing. We are seeing exploitation in that free trade zone in northern Mexico.
It is perfectly clear that Canada cannot be a net winner in this kind of an arrangement. We have seen under the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement the migration of plants to the southern United States. Even within the United States, Americans are noticing that there is an exodus out of the northern rust belt into the sun belt. The United States Congress is becoming increasingly

Government Orders
concerned that entering into a free trade deal with Mexico may not be in the best interest of American citizens. American corporations, yes.
Let us face it. When we tear away all of the dialogue and all of the rhetoric surrounding the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, there are people who benefited. The corporations benefited. They can do business more cheaply. They can make more money for their shareholders. For Canada and Canadians, unquestionably we were losers.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)

I listened to my hon. friend from Kamloops very carefully and I took down one sentence he used. It seems to me that my hon. friends in the New Democratic Party have shared a lot of gobbledegook with us today.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
I guess we will have a chance to debate the Canada-U.S.-Mexico free trade deal. I hope we never have that opportunity. That is one opportunity I would just as soon miss.
I believe, from what I have heard Canadians say, that they do not like the free trade agreement with the United States. They think it should be abrogated. speakerposition: Minister of State (Transport)
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has just said that he
speaks for Canadians who want the free trade agreement abrogated. There are others who do not. I think the facts speak for themselves. The Federation of Canadian Municipalities states in its latest publication: "Canadian exports to the U.S. have increased by 8 per cent since the agreement went into effect, but exports to the rest of the world have declined. Furthermore, since 1988, Canadian exports have performed more poorly in sectors where they were not subject to the free trade agreement".
I hope that we can keep our senses here so that we do not also have to abrogate a free trade deal with Canada, the United States and Mexico.
Also, Mr. Rutley, Economist for the Canadian Manufacturers' Association states:
Manufacturing job losses in industrialized countries during recessions traditionally average between five and eight per cent of the entire manufacturing work force. So far, Canada is in the middle, with 6.6. per cent loss between October 1989 and October 1990. By comparison, during the last recession of 1981-1982 and in the absence of a free trade agreement, losses were nearly double for the same period of time. Between October 1981 and October 1982, some 11.8 per cent of our manufacturing jobs were wiped out.
The article goes on to say:
Free trade has been and will continue to be good economic policy because it ensures access to the world's best market and forces Canada to become more efficient. About the only serious negative since free trade has been the misconceptions visited upon a gullible public.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, members of the Official Opposition, the Liberal Party of Canada, have observed in this legislation the complexity and the non-existence of explanatory notes as they pertain to all of these pieces of legislation.
The danger in passing a bill like this one is that perhaps the House of Commons is passing a major change to legislation that is called in the title non-controversial and of a non-complicated nature therein.
I was looking through this bill a moment ago and it has prompted me to make an intervention. I arrived at the portion of the bill, at page 15, concerning a change to the Coastal Fisheries Protection Act. The change is to paragraph 6(b). That is a famous part of that legislation. It is so controversial in Canada. In fact it is the most controversial part of any fisheries legislation that has ever passed in this country since we have been passing legislation. It is the most controversial part of the Coastal Fisheries Protection Act.
The explanatory notes say this:
Clause 43. This amendment, which would add the underlined and
sidelined words, would ensure that the terms and conditions that are
specified in licences need not be prescribed by regulation.
What licences? The amendment says:
(b) respecting the issuance, suspension and cancellation of any licences or permits-the fees payable-their terms and conditions-
Then the additional words: "which are in addition to such terms and conditions, if any, that the minister may specify therein".
I will tell you what this is. I do not blame the drafters of the legislation because they are not to blame. We have some of the best drafters of legislation in the world. It is what they are told to put in. The licences they are referring to here are the licences for foreign fishing vessels in Canadian waters.
Hidden away, not mentioned, they are the licences of foreign fishing vessels in Canadian waters. The bill now allows the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans to change
February 7, 1992

whatever portion of those licences he wishes and the fees to be charged in those licences.
There is such a thing as parliamentary democracy. We are supposed to be told these things because the people of Canada only know through this Parliament a lot of things that go on in government.
I am holding here a remission order that forgives the Government of France a half a million dollars on its fishing licences. When we pass this legislation we will never know when things such as this take place in the future. We will never know.
What the government does not explain in this legislation is that part A of the original act, the Coastal Fisheries Protection Act, sets out all of the terms and conditions of licences that are granted to foreign vessels to fish in Canadian waters. It spells them all out. It talks about the people who can work aboard those vessels, that is foreign crew members. It talks about what they can do, where they can go. It spells out all of those things.
In paragraph (b) that we are amending, it talks about the forms. It now says in an amendment that all of this, all that bill requiring it to be done by regulation can now be done by the minister.
How serious is that? Well, it is very serious. In this month, in this week, on this day there are foreign factory freezer trawlers licensed by the Government of Canada under these regulations off the coast of Canada up at a fishing zone called 2G and 2H. These trawlers receive their licences under this bill and they are fishing for codfish. They have a higher quota for cod in zones 2G and 2H on the Labrador coast than Canada does. They have a higher cod quota than Canada does.
Why is that so serious? It is so serious because we are now into the month of February. The month of February is the pre-spawning time for our codfish, the great northern cod stock that feeds all of our fish plants on the east coast of Canada. They are wintering and preparing for their spawning season in the month of March.
These are the only boats that are disturbing those spawning groups. It is not the ordinary Canadian inshore fisherman. He cannot get up there because of the ice. It is not the trawler of National Sea Products Limited or
Government Orders
Fisheries Products International. Why you could take a Canadian trawler of 175 feet long, drop it in the hold of one of those Soviet mother factory freezer trawler ships, they call them, and you would need search and rescue to find the Canadian boat. These are 470-foot vessels with the latest in technology.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader

speechtext: They've got a licence.

subtopic: MISCELLANEOUS STATUTE LAW AMENDMENT ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
They are licensed by the Government of Canada under the section we are dealing with here today. Under this section the minister will be able to give whatever licences he wants. He will be able to set whatever terms he wishes and he will be able to forgive the money that he forgave in a cabinet order for the government of France, but he will be able to do it Secretly.
It is not only the damage that is done to the spawning and the pre-spawning fish stocks, for four weeks those cod involve themselves in a very complex exercise prior to spawning and they cannot be disturbed. All of the scientific studies that have been done in Norway, Sweden and Denmark show that you cannot even drop food into that zone of pre-spawning activity because they will then not spawn. It is the foreign vessels licensed by Canada that is disturbing this process. Not only that, but they are catching fish.
The minister says: "Some of those fish are underutilized". Granted, you could say yes. I notice that nine foreign nations have quotas for what they call grenadier. I have never seen a grenadier in my life, but I am told it is a long, slinky fish with a great big swelled head like some people I know in the Government of Canada. They are given capelin that Canadians cannot fish because it is a restricted fishery. They are given squid and they are given mackerel. Mackerel is the only fish in the ocean that I know of that sinks if it stops swimming because it does not have an air bag, unlike some people in the government that I know. They are given herring. They are given fish that are restricted.
The other day, the minister of fisheries gave seven licences to Japan under this provision in the act to fish tuna. What did he do? He gave them a bigger quota in Canadian waters for bluefin than he gave to the fishermen of Canada. He even issued them an unlimited quota of albacore, big-eye, yellow-fin. Imagine, that is what you buy in the store in tins, the big-eye and the

February 7, 1992
Government Orders
yellow-fin. We say to the minister of fisheries: "Forget your yellow fin, open your big eye and kick them out".
Some are licensed under this section that I think should be pursued that we do not pursue. Tkke, for example, the ones that are licensed to go down around the riding for the hon. member from Cape Breton, our House leader, to catch sharks.
When you go to a restaurant and you pick up shark fin soup, that comes from a foreign vessel licensed by Canada from the Faeroes Islands. In fact, the name of the boat is Baker, not to be confused with Baker. They make a lot money as they fish for shark.
But all of those other licences granted by the Government of Canada, given permission to do so by regulation, change the licence by regulation, change the fees by regulation for giving France half a million dollars on their boat licences.
Now, under this bill the minister can do it by himself. Without going through any regulatory change, he can change the licences. He can issue the licences. He can give remission orders for non-payment.
Speaking of non-payment, do you know that today there are dozens of factory freezer trawlers from foreign nations that have not paid there fees for the last two years? Do you know what happens to Canadians if they do that? They do not get their licence.
This is a double standard. As our House leader pointed out one day back in December in the House of Commons, it is a system that has led to the destruction of our Canadian fishing resource.
Instead of passing a bill here today that allows the minister to further erode our resources behind the scenes, in his office on the weekends, to further erode in the secrecy of his office instead of going with orders, with cabinet decisions, with regulations, is a further destruction of our fishing resource.

Mr. Speaker, I congratulate my colleague from Gander-Grand Falls on such a superb intervention here this
afternoon. It brings to the attention of many members of Parliament some of the real serious issues that are affecting the fishing industry in Canada.
The seriousness with which this issue is put forward today also underlines, if you will, what I would deem the gross negligence of the Department of Fisheries and Oceans and in particular the minister responsible for that department who unfortunately is not here.
The minister is grossly negligent in responding to the concerns that Canadians have raised time and time again with regard to this particular provision that my colleague has so rightly pointed out.
The entire thrust of Bill C-35 and all of the amendments which are tied into this particular bill need further clarification, further debate, further examination by all members of this House.
In December of 19911 raised on the floor of the House the question as to why the government was proceeding to change the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency in sections 9 and 10 of Bill C-35.
This amendment would substitute the heading "Reports" for the heading "Annual Reports". It would better reflect that fact. Section 21 deals with more than annual reports.
It would mean in essence, instead of every year having a comprehensive report on the activities of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency, that they would only be coming forward every fifth year. I wonder why, and I think of the word sneaky. That is the word that I use.
I guess I was somewhat reflective over the holidays. I said to myself: "Perhaps that word was too strong, sneaky". I reflected and I went for a walk in the snow. I came back and I reflected again. I said to myself: "Is it sneaky, or is it not sneaky?"
Then my colleagues, unbeknownst to me, on December 24 gave me information that relieved me of some of the doubts I had with regard to words I used in this Chamber. I felt vindicated because I had used the word sneaky on several occasions.
What was given to me on December 24 was a series of documents outlining very clearly all the expenditures of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency during and just preceding the federal election of 1988. I was astounded.
February 7, 1992

Then I was given a second document only to find that three years later most, if not all, of the programs and projects for Enterprise Cape Breton for the year 1991 were reduced by over 80 per cent.
I use the word sneaky. I said the government was sneaky. I did not say the minister was sneaky because that would not be parliamentary. But sneaky is sneaky.
I think this government opposite has been exceptionally sneaky with the Canadian people and in particular those of us who reside in Atlantic Canada.
I would have hoped that on this particular day ministers of the Crown would avail themselves of the opportunity to participate in this important debate. I want to add I only see one minister of the Crown.

We were sold a bill of goods back some years ago. But now I understand why Bill C-35 is before the House. It is a sneaky bill. What do they want to do? They do not want us to review the comprehensive report. I would not say that the Minister of Transport or the Minister of State for Transport is sneaky. That would be inappropriate, but I suggest to the Chair that this bill and this government are sneaky. I feel very vindicated and I want to thank my colleagues-the hon. member for Cape Breton Highlands-Canso, the hon. member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys, the hon. member for Gander-Grand Falls and all my other colleagues in Atlantic Canada-for providing me with what I guess we could call somewhat of a Christmas present on December 24. They presented me with those documents which reaffirmed my suspicions about the activities of the government opposite as it relates to Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency.
Mr. Speaker, I am sure you would probably get unanimous consent for me to speak on. I am sure members opposite would want to hear me and would not want me to lose the opportunity to reveal more information as it pertains to ACOA. The fact is that this government has left an agency trumped up prior to election year as the panacea for economic development in Atlantic Canada. Recently it has been cut adrift by its political masters in Ottawa, namely the minister responsible for ACOA, the Prime Minister and the Minister of Finance.
All over Atlantic Canada we have example after example of Canadians without work, Canadians who have a desire to be at work, and a generation of young Canadians who have a great cause, the cause to participate in a Canadian economy so that they can make their contribution as individuals and perhaps subsequently, in later years, as spouses and family members.
This government precludes that opportunity. Time and time again it has put up road-blocks. It has not built roads. It has put up road-blocks.
Today 92,000 young people, more so than in January 1991, are without work as a result of the government opposite. All we get from the minister from Atlantic Canada, as we heard in Question Period today, is that he cannot do anything. He does not know what to do. He has no ideas. He has no principles with which to base any sort of sound public policy. All he does is sit and wait, fold his hands, cross his fingers and hope that the market forces will produce the necessaiy jobs for the young people across this country, including those in Atlantic Canada.

Government Orders
I say to members of the government opposite: "That is not good enough". For those of us who have entered public life to serve this country and try to assist individuals both young and old to improve their lot in Canadian society, I say to the government: "If you don't have the ideas, if you lack the political will to exercise whatever those thoughts may be, you ought to do the most prudent thing and that is to resign. If you can't resign, you should do the next best thing and that is call a general election and allow the people of Canada to decide".
Let me now talk about the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency and how it interfaces with other agencies of the Government of Canada. I have made references to Transport Canada. Let me make references, if I may, to Employment and Immigration.
Just last month in Halifax I was extended an invitation to attend a meeting of all the managers and senior staff of the CEIC offices in that province. I told each and every one in attendance that job development moneys, which have been put on hold by this government, were an absolute necessity in order to get people back to work. I have written to the minister on that. First I thanked him for extending an invitation for me to attend those deliberations. Then I told him that there were communities throughout this country with exceptionally high unemployment and very few prospects that the economic picture may change in coming weeks and months. I told him that he had a responsibility, whether it be in Lockeport, Glace Bay, Gander, the city of Montreal or the city of Ottawa, wherever those situations are, to try to assist.
Hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of my constituents in such municipalities as Glace Bay, New Waterford, Dominion, Cape Breton County and Richmond County have no hope of any foreseeable employment within the next 12 months.
The government says: "Where are we going to get the money?" I will throw out a little figure. In 1989 the advertising budget of this particular government was well over $75 million. That was so ministers of the Crown could get the seal of the Government of Canada, their pictures, their names, with PC, MP, or QC, whatever, on documents to distribute throughout the country.
When the Minister of Employment and Immigration stands weaving and bobbing that he does not know what he can do to assist the people of Canada, I suggest to him that he ought to do an examination of expenditures in house. Seventy-five million dollars would do wonders in constituencies like mine and Gander-Grand Falls. No, it would not be the panacea. It would not resolve the real turmoil these individuals are confronted with, but it certainly would be of some assistance. It could also help countless numbers of Canadians who are going to the food banks.
I have been a member of this House for almost 12 years. I have never seen it like it is today when I walk the streets here in Ottawa and I meet the great numbers of homeless people on the Sparks Street Mall, where stores are closing one after another.
This government has the unmitigated gall to say: "We do not have any money". It takes $75 million dollars to see the picture of the Solicitor General or the Minister of Labour, whose looks are surprisingly better than mine. At best you could hire them for a haunted house and make millions of dollars with them. I say to my colleagues opposite: Do not pour out your heart to us on the floor of the House of Commons that there is no money in the kitty. There is some money in the kitty, and it is your obligation to find those dollars and to spend them wisely and prudently for those individuals who need the assistance of the Crown at a very difficult time in Canadian history.
In the time I have remaining I want to say to members opposite that the situation is grave. The time for action is now. There is a call which has gone out across this country asking members of Parliament, and in particular members on the government side, to assess, to listen and, above all, to act.

effect that the minister of fisheries, my distinguished friend from St. John's West, was negligent.
To set the record straight, as the usual impartial observer I can be from time to time, maybe I should say to my friend from South Shore that instead of getting into a shouting match between himself and the gentleman from Cape Breton over whether he did or did not do it, maybe there is a more dispassionate way to decide whether this minister is even capable of negligence, this great friend of mine from St. John's West.
Let me give an example which is very much on the public record, an example that affects my own riding of Burin-St. George's more so than any other riding, an example which also has national implications. In so far as fishing treaties are concerned, two particular agreements were arrived at in recent years to which I would like to refer. First of all, I refer to the agreement setting up NAFO, the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization which flowed from the Law of the Sea Conference that established the 200-mile limit in 1977. That agreement provided that the 12 signatories, which we members of NAFO, to use the acronym, Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization for the fellows from Toronto, including Canada, including the European Community, in September of each year were to be assigned with respect to the following fishing season a certain quota, a certain allocation, a certain number of metric tons of fish which they could take, having due respect for conservation concerns of the fish stocks in the northwest Atlantic. A very simple and commendable process.
From 1977, as the member for South Shore will know, through 1978, 1979 and 1980 and through 1981, 1982, 1983,1984, every signatory, every one of the 12 members of NAFO without exception, therefore including the European Community which will become important later, honoured the agreement and stayed within the quota and there was no overfishing whatsoever, none.
Beginning in 1985 the system was the same but the results were different. Beginning in 1985, 11 of the 12 signatories continued to honour the agreement and one began to massively overfish. That one was the European Community and specifically two members of that community, Spain and Portugal.
Beginning in 1985 that member of the European Community whose quota was 23,200 metric tons actually take 23,200 metric tons. In 1985 it took 172,000 metric tons. It took eight times its quota.
In 1986 it took 12 times its quota, 12 times as much fish as it was supposed to take under an agreement which it had signed. And so it went on. In 1985 and 1986 there was massive abuse, massive destruction, massive pillaging of the fish stocks that my people in Burin-St. George's and people elsewhere in Newfoundland depend on for their livelihood, either as workers in fish plants or as fishermen and fisherwomen on the boats.
That massive, unconscionable pillaging went on through 1985, 1986, 1987, 1988. It went on through 1989 and 1990 and has gone on through 1991. I predict it will go on through 1992. That is one-half of the example. Let me give you the other half. That is the NAFO issue and I have told how there was massive abuse of the fishing in respect to that agreement.
There was another agreement signed between Canada and France, a bilateral agreement just between those two countries, addressing fisheries issues and the fishing rights of those two countries in so far as the Gulf of St. Lawrence and an area known as 3PS, an area basically south of the island of Newfoundland and around the islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon. There were agreements signed there that allowed, among other things, for France to take certain quotas. That agreement was signed in 1972 and it said that, depending on the advice of scientists and marine biologists, France would be allowed to take a certain tonnage each year. That agreement was signed in 1972. Would you believe that beginning with that agreement, for 1973 and 1974 and 1975 and each year thereafter, France stayed within the quota. Whatever the quota was for that year, it took. Whatever it was for 1975, it took; for 1976, it took. It never exceeded the quota. Right up until and including 1984 France honoured that agreement and stayed within the quota of fish it was allowed to catch off the coast of Newfoundland and Nova Scotia.
Beginning in 1985 things changed dramatically. Instead of catching its 1985 quota of 9,500 tonnes France took 25,800 tonnes. In 1986, instead of staying within its quota of 9,500 tonnes, France took 26,000 tonnes. In short, beginning in 1985 France began to take approximately

three times its quota under its bilateral agreement between Canada and France.
France has continued to do that essentially until this day or, to be more correct, until a year or so ago when this government entered into an agreement, and the purpose of this latter agreement of 1990 or 1991 was right. The purpose was right. The methodology was a bit naive but the purpose was right. It was to get France to the table, which it did.
However, the way it did it was to say: "France, you have been stealing from us. Instead of taking 9,500 tonnes which you are allowed under the agreement, you are taking 26,000. Let's make a deal. Instead of stealing
26,000,	will you agree just to steal 17,000? How is that for a deal? We will let you steal fish but only steal twice as much as you are supposed to, instead of three times as much". That is an aside.
The real point I want to make is that in 1977 NAFO signed an agreement and until 1984 that agreement was honoured. Beginning in 1985 the European Community abused it terribly.
On the other hand France signed an agreement with Canada which it continued to honour until 1985, at which time it began to abuse it terribly. I have given the figures.
In both cases there was agreement and both sides worked within the agreement until and including 1984. There was abuse of the agreement beginning in 1985 and has been ever since. Why did massive overfishing begin in both cases in 1985? The short answer must concern the fact that there was a change of government and with it a very definite change of approach as to how to treat France, Portugal and Spain.
As of 1985 the message went out to Portugal, Spain and France that a new crowd was in charge over here, a crowd that did not care how much they pillaged the fish stocks, how many Newfoundlanders in fish plants they put out of work, how many fishermen from Nova Scotia and Newfoundland they put out of work in the fishing boats. "Pillage the stock if that is the way you feel", was the net message that went out.
What does this have to do with what my friend from South Shore asked a minute ago when he was a little concerned about the suggestion that the minister from

St. John's West could be characterized as negligent? He is a minister, bless his cotton-picking soul, the only minister we have had in the cabinet from Newfoundland since September 1984. There has been no other, just him, just that one man from September 1984 until the present. The overfishing began in 1985, within six months of his becoming the minister.
The French, Spanish and Portuguese walked off with literally tens of thousands of tonnes. They wiped out thousands and thousands of Newfoundlanders' jobs, those of the minister's fellow countrymen and some of his fellow constituents. They caused a shutdown at the plant at Trepassey in his riding because of fish stocks. They caused a shutdown of the plant in St. John's in his riding as a result of the fish stocks issue. What was he doing?
Mr. Speaker, do you believe, and if you do not just check Hansard, that from 1984 through 1985 when overfishing by those three countries began it continued through 1986, 1987 and 1988?
How many times was the overfishing by foreigners issue raised publicly in this House? It was raised once in four years. In 1985-86, 1987-88, it was raised once. In December of 1988, four years after the overfishing began, it was raised in this Chamber for the first time. I know because I am the one who raised it after I was elected here in November 1988. That is the first time it was raised in this Chamber by anybody.
What more graphic example of gross disgusting negligence could you have than that? A minister lets thousands of his fellow countrymen, thousands of his constituents, plant workers and fishermen go down the economic drain because he is tied to a policy that says "Do not rock the boat, fellows. If the Portuguese and the Spaniards, the French and the Europeans want a few tonnes of fish, let them take the fish, all the fish they want, but do not rock the boat because our Prime Minister, our boy from Baie Comeau, is trying to be a statesman out there. He wants to be buddies with Mitterrand. What do a few fishermen's lives have to do with this? What do a few plant workers' livelihoods have to do with it all? Do not rock the boat, Crosbie. Do not rock the boat, minister from St. John's West".

The accusation against that minister is not negligence. That is too good a term for what he did. The accusation is much worse than that. In graphically simple terms, he abandoned thousands of people in his riding, plant workers and fishermen, and thousands more in my riding, tens of thousands in total, rather than break with a policy that was absolutely unconscionable and that was designed to be the death-knell for the Atlantic fishery.
Luckily and to his credit, and he needs some credit because he committed such an atrocious sin in respect to the other in allowing this to go on silently for four years, the minister has lately decided that enough is enough and now he is out there, belatedly albeit, being the champion on the overfishing issue. It is almost certainly a case of closing the bam after the horse is gone.
His voice is now vibrant in 1992 on overfishing as he trips around the citadels and the capitals of the world. If we had only had it in 1985 in cabinet. If we had only had it speaking up about the jobs in Trepassey and St. John's and those other places I could mention, places in my riding. I mentioned a couple in the minister's riding. That is what he has to answer for. He is playing one awfully big game of catch-up these days, trying to undo some of the misery he inflicted on those people by his silence. I say to the member for South Shore, who I understand has to come in here and toe the line and keep an eye on that crowd, those boys, watch the fellows from Gander-Grand Falls and Burin-St. George's and Cape Breton eastward.
Watch what they say and then get up and try to poke a few holes in it and, if they say a nasty word like negligence, get up and look intelligent and show the people across the country that we take them on. If they want to know, if they want to challenge my colleague's use of negligence, I have just given them an example. If they want some more examples, I can give them more. I cannot give one that is any more graphic than the one I have just given. Literally thousands of jobs of fishermen and plant workers in my riding and in the minister's riding of St. John's West have gone down the drain because of the negligence, the failure to act by that minister.
That will be part of his legacy. He can undo it somewhat if he would do what we have been saying he
should do: say to the Europeans they have have had enough time. We in Canada are going to unilaterally extend the continental shelf to take in the nose and tail of the Grand Banks and the Flemish Cap, those three little outgrowths where the fish spend some of their time when they are not inside the Canadian line. It is when they are outside that line of course that they become vulnerable to the pillaging I talked about a little while ago.
I am sure in time my good friend the minister from St. John's West, the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, will want to-hopefully before this debate is over-stand and give his side of the story, why it was he was absolutely silent, muzzled, for four entire years, never made one peep in this House, outside this House, not one living peep. Nothing. Zilch. For four years he watched jobs being wiped out and industry being absolutely pulverized by his neglect, his negligence, his failure to go to the Prime Minister, be a man about it, and say he could not stand by and let this be done to his fellow Newfoundlanders, to his fellow Canadians. That is what he should have done. That is what he did not do and I say to my friends on South Shore that is what I call negligence. Maybe he has a nicer word for it.
